page.title: 09Bee-Keeping In Braydon
page.content: A farmer in Braydon enjoys bee-keeping as a hobby. Starting from one hive, he now has 17 hives. Surplus honey is sold to local customers. Bee-keepers feed the bees with sugar water syrup to stimulate them in April. The hives are visited every 9 days during the summer for the purpose of swarm control. Protective clothing of veil, gloves and trousers is worn. The honey is collected during August. The bees are fed again in September and then left until the following Spring when the cycle starts again. In Braydon the bees would feed primarily on clover. This wet and cool summer of 1985 has been disastrous for clover as temperatures of 21 C are required from June to July.
